<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior
to the distribution of Verigy shares, Verigy and Agilent, and, in some cases, their respective subsidiaries, entered into agreements providing for the June&nbsp;1, 2006
separation of the semiconductor test solutions business from Agilent, including a master separation and distribution agreement. These agreements cover a variety of matters, including the transfer,
ownership and licensing of intellectual property and other assets and liabilities relating to Verigy's businesses, the use of shared facilities, employee and tax-related matters and the
transitional services Agilent will provide to Verigy. In addition, an ancillary agreement provided for a $25&nbsp;million revolving credit facility from Agilent to Verigy on the separation date with
interest at one-month LIBOR plus 50 basis points. All amounts were repaid back and the credit facility has expired. The agreements relating to the separation from Agilent have been
negotiated in the context of a parent-subsidiary relationship. Per the transitional services agreement, the majority of the services Agilent provided to Verigy upon separation terminated prior to the
distribution date. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Indemnifications to Verigy  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the spin-off of Verigy, we agreed to indemnify Verigy and its affiliates against damages which it might incur in the future. These
indemnifications primarily cover damages relating to liabilities of the businesses that Agilent retained and did not transfer to Verigy, liabilities that might </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>76</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=76,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=226482,FOLIO='76',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EE1318A.;15',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:31' -->
<A NAME="page_ee1318_1_77"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>arise
under limited portions of Verigy's IPO materials that relate to Agilent, and costs and expenses incurred by Agilent or Verigy to effect the IPO, arising out of the distribution of Agilent's
remaining holding in Verigy ordinary shares to Agilent's stockholders, or incurred to effect the separation of the semiconductor test solutions business from Agilent to the extent incurred prior to
the separation on June&nbsp;1, 2006. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Share-Based Compensation  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective November&nbsp;1, 2005, Agilent adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)&nbsp;which requires the measurement and recognition of compensation
expense for all share-based payment awards made to our employees and directors including employee stock option awards, employee stock purchases made under our ESPP and performance share awards granted
to selected members of our senior management under the LTPP based on estimated fair values. Agilent previously applied the provisions of APB No.&nbsp;25 and related Interpretations and provided the
required pro forma disclosures under SFAS No.&nbsp;123, "Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation," ("SFAS No.&nbsp;123"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Description of Share-Based Plans  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee stock purchase plans.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective November&nbsp;1, 2000, we adopted the ESPP. Under the provisions of the ESPP,
eligible employees may contribute up to ten percent of their base compensation to purchase shares of our common stock at 85&nbsp;percent of the lower of the fair market value at the entry date or
the purchase date as defined by the ESPP. The ESPP has a maximum contractual term of two years. As of October&nbsp;31, 2006, securities authorized and available for issuance in connection with our
ESPP were 23,341,919. Shares authorized for issuance in connection with the ESPP are subject to an automatic annual increase of the lesser of one percent of the outstanding common stock of Agilent or
an amount determined by the Compensation Committee of our Board of Directors. Under the terms of the ESPP, in no event shall the number of shares authorized for issuance in connection with the ESPP
exceed 75&nbsp;million shares. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Incentive compensation plans.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;17, 1999, we adopted the Agilent Technologies,&nbsp;Inc. 1999 Stock Plan
(the "Stock Plan") and subsequently reserved 67,800,000 shares of our common stock for issuance under the Stock Plan. In addition, on May&nbsp;31, 2000, 19,000,000 shares of our common stock were
registered pursuant to converted stock options previously granted by HP. In February&nbsp;2001, our stockholders approved an additional 45,000,000 shares of our common stock for issuance under the
Stock Plan. These shares were subsequently registered in May&nbsp;2002. At October&nbsp;31, 2006, shares registered and available for option and restricted stock grants were 36,639,572. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock
options, stock appreciation rights, stock awards and cash awards may be granted under the Stock Plan. Options granted under the Stock Plan may be either "incentive stock options",
as defined in section&nbsp;422 of the Internal Revenue Code, or non-statutory. Options generally vest at a rate of 25&nbsp;percent per year over a period of four years from the date of
grant and generally have a maximum contractual term of ten years. The exercise price for stock options is generally not less than 100&nbsp;percent of the fair market value of our common stock on the
date the stock award is granted. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
March&nbsp;4, 2003, our stockholders approved an amendment to the Stock Plan. The amendment permitted the company to offer a one-time exchange of options issued under
the Stock Plan having an exercise price greater than $25 for a lesser number of options to be granted at least six months and one day from the cancellation of surrendered options (the "Option Exchange
Program"). On May&nbsp;20, 2003, we implemented the Option Exchange Program by filing a Tender Offer Statement with the SEC, which </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>77</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=77,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=34807,FOLIO='77',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EE1318A.;15',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:31' -->
<A NAME="page_ee1318_1_78"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>allowed
eligible employees a one-time opportunity to exchange options to purchase shares of the company's common stock, whether vested or unvested, which were granted under our Stock Plan,
with exercise prices greater than $25 per share. The Option Exchange Program was offered from May&nbsp;20, 2003 to June&nbsp;18, 2003 and options to purchase approximately 26&nbsp;million shares
were exchanged, with an average exercise price of $51. As a result, the company issued options to purchase approximately 13.8&nbsp;million shares at a weighted-average exercise price of $28 per
share during the first quarter of 2004. Under the provisions of APB No.&nbsp;25 no compensation expense was recognized in our consolidated statement of operations for issuance of the replacement
options for fiscal years ended 2005 and 2004. As a result of the SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)&nbsp;adoption, in fiscal year ended 2006, we recognized approximately $3&nbsp;million in our consolidated
statement of operations for the issuance of these replacement options. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
November&nbsp;1, 2003, the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors approved the LTPP for the company's executive officers and other key employees beginning in 2006.
Participants in this program are entitled to receive unrestricted shares of the company's stock after the end of a three-year period, if specified performance targets are met. The maximum
contractual term for awards under the LTPP plan is three years. The following table summarizes the shares approved by the Compensation Committee to be issued under the LTPP: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="73%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
all cases, the final award may vary as it is based on certain performance metrics. We consider the dilutive impact of this program in our diluted net income per share calculation only
to the extent that the performance conditions are met. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Pro forma Information for Periods Prior to the Adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R), Agilent provided the disclosures required under SFAS No.&nbsp;123, as amended by SFAS No.&nbsp;148,
"Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation&nbsp;&#151; Transition and Disclosures." No employee share-based compensation expense was reflected in our results from continuing operations in 2005
and 2004 for employee stock option awards as all options were granted with an exercise price equal to the market value of the underlying common stock on the date of grant. Our ESPP was deemed
non-compensatory under the provisions of APB No.&nbsp;25. Compensation expense for the non-vested performance shares granted under the LTPP was recognized based on the grant
date fair value for the respective grants. Forfeitures of awards were recognized as they occurred. We recorded APB No.&nbsp;25 compensation expense in continuing operations of $8&nbsp;million in
2005 and $7&nbsp;million in 2004. The APB No.&nbsp;25 compensation expense in 2005 and 2004 primarily related to our LTPP. In August&nbsp;2005 our Board of Directors approved a modification to
the terms of the options held by employees of our semiconductor products business to effect the acceleration of vesting for all unvested options held by employees of that business, effective as of the
date of the sale of the semiconductor products business to Avago. In connection with this modification, we recorded $8&nbsp;million of compensation expense in discontinued operations. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>78</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
pro forma results in 2005 and 2004 include approximately $32&nbsp;million and $70&nbsp;million of pro forma compensation expense relating to our Option Exchange Program,
respectively. The remainder of the expense for those periods related to awards granted over the previous four years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due
to the valuation allowance provided on our net deferred tax assets as described in Note&nbsp;8, "Provision (Benefit) for Income Taxes from Continuing Operations", we did not record
any tax benefits attributable to pro forma share-based compensation expenses for employees in the U.S. and certain other foreign jurisdictions in 2005 and 2004. The tax impact presented above was
computed for both the APB No.&nbsp;25 and SFAS No.&nbsp;123 share-based compensation expense. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Impact of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Agilent adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)&nbsp;using the modified prospective transition method beginning November&nbsp;1, 2005. Accordingly, in 2006, we
recorded share-based compensation expense for awards granted prior to but not yet vested as of November&nbsp;1, 2005 as if the fair value method required for pro forma disclosure under SFAS
No.&nbsp;123 were in effect for expense recognition purposes adjusted for estimated forfeitures. The effect of forfeitures on the unamortized compensation expense of pre-adoption awards was not
material. For these awards, we have continued to recognize compensation expense using the accelerated amortization method under FIN No.&nbsp;28. For share-based awards granted after
November&nbsp;1, 2005 we have recognized compensation expense based on the estimated grant date fair value method required under SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R). For these awards we have recognized
compensation expense using a straight-line amortization method. As SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)&nbsp;requires that share-based compensation expense be based on awards that are ultimately
expected to vest, estimated share-based compensation in 2006 has been reduced for estimated forfeitures. Amounts previously reported prior to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)&nbsp;have not
been restated. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>79</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
October&nbsp;31, 2006 there was no share-based compensation capitalized within inventory as it was immaterial. Total income tax benefit recognized in 2006 in the statement of
operations for share-based compensation was immaterial. The weighted average grant date fair value of options, as determined under SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R), granted in 2006 was $10.46 per share. The
total fair value of shares vested in 2006 was $216&nbsp;million. In 2006 the windfall tax benefit realized from exercised stock options and similar awards was immaterial. As of October&nbsp;31,
2006, the total unrecorded deferred share-based compensation balance for non-vested shares, net of expected forfeitures, was approximately $88&nbsp;million which is expected to be
amortized over a weighted-average period of 2.3&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Included
in income from and gain on sale of discontinued operations of our semiconductor products business and recorded under the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)&nbsp;for the
fiscal year ended 2006 is approximately $3&nbsp;million of share-based compensation expense in connection with the 2005 modification to the terms of the options held by employees of our divested
semiconductor products business. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>80</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=80,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=486021,FOLIO='80',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EE1318A.;15',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:31' -->
<A NAME="page_ee1318_1_81"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Included
in income from discontinued operations of our semiconductor test solutions business and recorded under the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)&nbsp;is $9&nbsp;million of
share-based compensation expense for Agilent options held by Verigy employees and $2&nbsp;million of new Verigy awards that were issued prior to the final distribution of Verigy shares by Agilent.
As a result of the final distribution of Verigy shares by Agilent which took place on October&nbsp;31, 2006, non-vested Agilent stock options held by Verigy employees were cancelled.
Vested Agilent stock options held by Verigy employees will have a period of up to three months in which to exercise the Agilent options before such options are cancelled. Retirement eligible Verigy
employees will have a period of up to three years in which to exercise the Agilent options before such options are cancelled. To the extent that the Agilent options were not vested as of the
distribution date, Verigy issued replacement Verigy awards. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Valuation Assumptions  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For all periods presented, the fair value of share-based awards for employee stock option awards, restricted stock and employee stock purchases made under our
ESPP was estimated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model. In 2006, shares granted under the LTPP were valued using a Monte Carlo simulation. In 2005 and 2004, shares granted under the LTPP were
valued using the variable accounting method under APB No.&nbsp;25. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
weighted average assumptions used for options granted, ESPP purchases and the LTPP in 2006, 2005 and 2004 was as follows: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>81</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=81,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=977112,FOLIO='81',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EE1318A.;15',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:31' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_eg1318_1_82"> </A> </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Both the Black-Scholes and Monte Carlo simulation fair value models require the use of highly subjective and complex assumptions, including the option's expected
life and the price volatility of the underlying stock. Beginning November&nbsp;1, 2005, the expected stock price volatility assumption was determined using the implied volatility for our stock.
Prior to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R), we used a combination of historical and implied volatility in deriving our expected volatility assumption. We have determined that implied volatility
is more reflective of market conditions and a better indicator of expected volatility than a combined method of determining volatility. We consider several factors in estimating the expected life of
our options granted, including the expected lives used by a peer group of companies and the historical option exercise behavior of our employees, which we believe are representative of future
behavior. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Share-Based Payment Award Activity  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table summarizes equity share-based payment award activity in 2006: </FONT></P>

plan shares expired per the above table represent cancelled options granted under the HP stock option plan that are not added back to our available for grant options as the plan
shares expire after cancellation and are not reissuable. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate intrinsic value in the table above represents the total pre-tax intrinsic value, based on the company's closing stock
price of $35.60 at October&nbsp;31, 2006, which would have been received by award holders had all award holders exercised their awards that were in-the-money as of that date.
The total number of in-the-money awards exercisable at October&nbsp;31, 2006 was approximately 33&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
amount of cash received from the exercise of share-based awards granted was $547&nbsp;million in 2006, $198&nbsp;million in 2005 and $137&nbsp;million in 2004. See
Note&nbsp;8, "Provision (Benefit) for Income Taxes from Continuing Operations" for the tax impact on share-based award exercises. </FONT></P>

income is derived principally from short-term commercial paper for our restricted investments and the investment of our surplus cash balances in bank time deposits
and other money market instruments. Income from Foreign Sales Corporation Tax Study was earned pursuant to an agreement with Hewlett-Packard to provide assistance with a Foreign Sales Corporation

<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=84,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=65188,FOLIO='84',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EG1318A.;16',USER='CMATTI',CD='21-DEC-2006;22:13' -->
<A NAME="page_eg1318_1_85"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Study
for years prior to the 2000 spin-off of Agilent from Hewlett-Packard. For its services, Agilent earned a fee which was contingent on related tax benefits being realized. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity in Net Income of Unconsolidated Affiliate and Gain on Sale&nbsp;&#151; Lumileds  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lumileds Lighting International, B.V. ("Lumileds"), was a global joint venture between Agilent and Koninklijke Philips Electronics N.V. ("Philips") under a Second
Amended and Restated Joint Venture Agreement (the "Joint Venture Agreement"), dated as of November&nbsp;29, 2004, between Agilent and Philips. Lumileds manufactures high-power light
emitting diodes and solid-state lighting solutions. Our ownership interest in Lumileds was approximately 47&nbsp;percent as of October&nbsp;31, 2005, after selling 1&nbsp;percent of our interest
to Philips in the second quarter of 2005. Our equity in the net income of our unconsolidated affiliate including the gain on sale of our interest in Lumileds was $901&nbsp;million in 2006,
$42&nbsp;million in 2005 and $29&nbsp;million in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
November&nbsp;28, 2005, we completed the sale of our stake in Lumileds. Pursuant to the Share Purchase Agreement, upon closure of the sale transaction, the Joint Venture Agreement
and the ancillary agreements were terminated. The purchase price paid by Philips under the Share Purchase Agreement was $949&nbsp;million. In addition, Lumileds repaid the $51&nbsp;million of
outstanding principal debt and accrued interest due to us as of the date of sale under the Credit Agreement, dated as of November&nbsp;30, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table shows the components of the gain from sale of Lumileds, net of income tax (in millions): </FONT></P>

federal and state provisions do not reflect tax savings resulting from deductions associated with our stock option plans. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>86</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=86,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=73509,FOLIO='86',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EI1318A.;13',USER='CMATTI',CD='21-DEC-2006;22:29' -->
<A NAME="page_ei1318_1_87"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
consolidated balance sheet reflects the allocation of the valuation allowance based on the pro-rata portion of gross current and non-current deferred tax
assets in each jurisdiction where a valuation allowance is required. During 2003, we established valuation allowances for the deferred tax assets of the U.S. and selected entities in foreign
jurisdictions. The valuation allowances were determined in accordance with the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;109, which require an assessment of both positive and negative evidence when determining
whether it is more likely than not that deferred tax assets are recoverable. Such assessment is required on a jurisdiction-by-jurisdiction basis. Cumulative losses incurred in
the U.S. and certain entities in foreign jurisdictions in recent years represented sufficient negative evidence to require full valuation allowances. We intend to maintain full valuation allowances
until sufficient positive evidence exists to support reversal. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
October&nbsp;31, 2006, we had federal net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $256&nbsp;million and tax credit carryforwards of approximately $145&nbsp;million. The
federal net operating losses expire in years beginning 2007 through 2021, if not utilized. The federal tax credits expire beginning in 2007 through 2026, if not utilized. In addition, the company has
state tax credit carryforwards of $133&nbsp;million. State tax credits of $18&nbsp;million expire beginning in 2007 through
2018, if not utilized. A portion of the federal and state net operating losses and certain tax credit carryforwards are subject to change of ownership limitations provided by the Internal Revenue Code
and similar state provisions. These annual loss limitations may result in the expiration or reduced utilization of the net operating losses and/or credits. At October&nbsp;31, 2006, we also had
foreign net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $390&nbsp;million. Of this foreign loss, $127&nbsp;million will expire in years beginning 2011 through 2014, if not utilized. The
remaining $263&nbsp;million has an indefinite life. Some of the foreign losses are subject to annual loss limitation rules. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
deferred tax assets of approximately $79&nbsp;million at October&nbsp;31, 2006 and approximately $32&nbsp;million at October&nbsp;31, 2005 pertain to net operating loss
carryforwards resulting from the exercise of employee stock options, which have been fully offset by a valuation allowance. When recognized, the reversal of the valuation allowance will be accounted
for as a credit to shareholders' equity rather than as a reduction of the income tax provision. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
differences between the U.S. federal statutory income tax rate and our effective tax rate from continuing operations are: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="71%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="66%" ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
income tax provision for 2006 includes a benefit of $29&nbsp;million related to the resolution of domestic tax-related issues for years covered by a Tax Sharing
Agreement between Agilent and Hewlett-Packard. The Tax Sharing Agreement is related to the 2000 spin-off of Agilent from Hewlett-Packard. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
October&nbsp;22, 2004, the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 ("AJCA") was signed into law. The AJCA creates a temporary incentive for U.S. corporations to repatriate accumulated
income earned abroad by providing an 85&nbsp;percent dividends received deduction for certain dividends from controlled foreign corporations. In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2005, we distributed
cash from our foreign subsidiaries and reported an extraordinary dividend (as defined in the AJCA) of $970&nbsp;million and a related tax liability of approximately $48&nbsp;million in our fiscal
2005 federal and state income tax returns. For fiscal 2005, $23&nbsp;million of the $48&nbsp;million is provided for in the discontinuing operations' provision for income taxes while the remaining
is provided for in the continuing operations' provision for income taxes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Agilent
has not recorded deferred income taxes on the undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries. Our policy is to continue to invest the undistributed earnings of our foreign
subsidiaries indefinitely outside of the United States, with the exception of the amounts repatriated in the year ended October&nbsp;31, 2005 under the AJCA. If management decides to remit
this income to the U.S. in a future period, our provision for income taxes may increase materially in that period. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Agilent
enjoys tax holidays in several different jurisdictions, most significantly in Singapore, Malaysia and Switzerland. The tax holidays provide lower rates of taxation on certain
classes of income and require various thresholds of investments and employment in those jurisdictions. During the years 2003 through 2006, Agilent enjoyed tax holidays that applied to manufacturing
income generated in Malaysia and Singapore. The tax holidays in both Malaysia and Singapore expire in 2013. In 2004, Agilent secured a reduced tax rate in Switzerland for income generated from
activity that Agilent began in Switzerland during that year. The tax holiday expires in 2013. Also in 2004, Agilent secured an additional Singapore tax holiday for earnings from investments and
related activity that began in 2004. The tax holiday applies to applicable earnings of Agilent until the end of 2013, with the opportunity for a reduced rate thereafter. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
a result of the incentives, the impact of the tax holidays decreased income taxes by $76&nbsp;million, $54&nbsp;million and $96&nbsp;million in 2006, 2005 and 2004,
respectively. The benefit of the tax holidays on net income per share (diluted) was approximately $0.17, $0.11 and $0.20 in 2006, 2005 and 2003, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>88</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=88,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=824181,FOLIO='88',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EI1318A.;13',USER='CMATTI',CD='21-DEC-2006;22:29' -->
<A NAME="page_ei1318_1_89"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
are subject to ongoing tax examinations of our tax returns by the Internal Revenue Service and other tax authorities in various jurisdictions. We regularly assess the likelihood of
adverse outcomes resulting from these examinations to determine the adequacy of our provision for income taxes. These assessments can require considerable estimates and judgments. If our estimate of
income tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate assessment, a further charge to expense would be required. If events occur and the payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be
unnecessary, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
computing diluted net income per share under the treasury stock method, we elected to use the transition election of FSP SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R)-3 to determine the pool of
windfall tax benefits as of the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (R). For further details see Note&nbsp;2, "New Accounting Pronouncements." The total number of awards exercised in 2006, 2005 and 2004
was 19&nbsp;million, 5&nbsp;million and 3&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with the October&nbsp;31, 2006 Verigy distribution, on November&nbsp;1, 2006 Agilent distributed .122435 of an ordinary share of Verigy for each outstanding share of
Agilent common stock owned as of October&nbsp;16, 2006 to Agilent's stockholders. In addition, under the anti-dilution provision of the 1999 Stock Plan, on November&nbsp;1, 2006
Agilent adjusted the exercise price downward and number of option shares upward for each outstanding employee stock option to preserve the value of the options after the Verigy spin-off.
For further details on the distribution see Note&nbsp;5, "Share-Based Compensation." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
computation of diluted net income per share for the fiscal year 2004 does not include 36&nbsp;million shares issuable upon conversion of our then outstanding $1.15&nbsp;billion
senior convertible debenture as the effect was not dilutive for this period, using the if-converted method pursuant to SFAS No.&nbsp;128, "Earnings per Share". Our convertible debt was
redeemed as of September&nbsp;9, 2005 and therefore not part of the computation in 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>10.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Supplemental Cash Flow Information  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash paid for income taxes was $156&nbsp;million in 2006, $75&nbsp;million in 2005 and $149&nbsp;million in 2004. Cash paid for interest was
$55&nbsp;million in 2006, $44&nbsp;million in 2005 and $36&nbsp;million in 2004. In 2006, we spent $25&nbsp;million as debt issuance costs related to our long-term debt of
$1.5&nbsp;billion and amortized $4&nbsp;million in interest expense during 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non
cash transactions in 2005 primarily related to the conversion of approximately $466&nbsp;million of the principal amount of convertible debt into common stock. In addition, accrued
interest of approximately $4&nbsp;million relating to the convertible debt was recorded in equity as part of the cost of the new shares issued. Non-cash transactions in 2004 related
primarily to an acquisition in October&nbsp;2004 and we issued approximately 772,000 shares with an approximate value of $18&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restricted Cash and Cash Equivalents  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of October&nbsp;31, 2006, $1,606&nbsp;million was reported as restricted cash and cash equivalents on our consolidated balance sheet. Of this amount,
$1,582&nbsp;million was short-term restricted commercial paper maintained in connection with our obligations to a counterparty pursuant to the Master Repurchase Agreement and related
Confirmation entered into on January&nbsp;27, 2006 and reported as long-term debt on our consolidated balance sheet. See Note&nbsp;21, "Long-Term Debt and Credit
Facilities." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
sold our San Jose site for a total consideration of $88&nbsp;million and recorded a gain of $56&nbsp;million during the second quarter of 2006. In May&nbsp;2006, we completed
the sale of our Palo Alto site for a total consideration of $98.5&nbsp;million and recorded a gain of $65&nbsp;million. Asset impairments other than restructuring were zero in 2006,
$4&nbsp;million in 2005, and zero in 2004. Depreciation
expenses for continuing operations were $141&nbsp;million in 2006, $163&nbsp;million in 2005 and $189&nbsp;million in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
purchased $69&nbsp;million of other intangibles and recorded $76&nbsp;million of goodwill during 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February&nbsp;2006, we acquired the remaining 49&nbsp;percent minority interest in Yokogawa Analytical Systems, a joint venture between Agilent and Yokogawa Electrical
Corporation. This acquisition resulted in the recording of $43&nbsp;million in intangible assets and $60&nbsp;million of goodwill. In addition, during 2006 we recorded two acquisitions, one earn
out payment on an acquisition completed in 2005, and one joint venture buyout payment. Pro forma disclosures are not presented for these transactions as they were not material. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization
of intangible assets was $24&nbsp;million in 2006, $13&nbsp;million in 2005 and $17&nbsp;million in 2004. Future amortization expense related to existing intangible
assets is estimated to be $27&nbsp;million in 2007, $19&nbsp;million in 2008, $12&nbsp;million in 2009, $10&nbsp;million in 2010, $7&nbsp;million in 2011 and $8&nbsp;million thereafter. </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>172</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>269</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="75%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>92</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=92,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=978569,FOLIO='92',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EI1318A.;13',USER='CMATTI',CD='21-DEC-2006;22:29' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_ek1318_1_93"> </A> </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost method investments consist of non-marketable equity securities and are accounted for at historical cost. For investments where we have
significant influence over the investee, the equity method of accounting is used. Agilent's proportionate share of income or loss for equity method investments was recorded currently in earnings.
Trading securities are reported at fair value, with gains or losses resulting from changes in fair value recognized currently in operating earnings. Investments designated as
available-for-sale are reported at fair value, with unrealized gains and losses, net of tax, included in stockholders' equity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All
of our investments (excluding trading securities) are subject to periodic impairment review. However, the impairment analysis requires significant judgment to identify events or
circumstances that would likely have significant adverse effect on the future value of the investment. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Charges
related to other than temporary impairments were $1&nbsp;million in 2006, $18&nbsp;million in 2005 and $15&nbsp;million in 2004. These impairment charges were recorded in
other income (expense), net in the consolidated statement of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized
gains and losses on our trading securities portfolio were $6&nbsp;million gain in 2006 and $5&nbsp;million gain in both 2005 and 2004. Realized gains and losses from the
sale of available-for-sale securities was $9&nbsp;million in 2006, $8&nbsp;million in 2005 and zero in 2004. Realized gains and losses from the sale of
held-to-maturity securities was $2&nbsp;million in 2006, zero in 2005 and zero in 2004. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, we sold our remaining interest in Lumileds to Philips. See Note&nbsp;7, "Equity in Net Income of Unconsolidated Affiliate and Gain on
Sale&nbsp;&#151; Lumileds "for further details. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>16.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Retirement Plans and Post Retirement Pension Plans  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;General.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Substantially all of our employees are covered under various defined benefit and/or defined contribution plans.
Additionally, we sponsor post-retirement health care benefits and a death benefit under the Agilent Survivor Protection Plan for our eligible U.S. employees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Agilent
provides U.S. employees, who meet eligibility criteria under the retirement and deferred profit-sharing plans, defined benefits which are generally based on an employee's highest
five consecutive years' average pay during the years of employment and on length of service. For eligible service through October&nbsp;31, 1993, the benefit payable under the Agilent Retirement Plan
is reduced by any amounts due to the eligible employee under our defined contribution Deferred Profit-Sharing Plan ("DPSP"), which was closed to new participants as of November&nbsp;1993. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of October&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the fair value of plan assets and the total projected benefit obligation of the DPSP for U.S. Agilent Employees were $726&nbsp;million and
$826&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Eligible
employees outside the U.S. generally receive retirement benefits under various retirement plans based upon factors such as years of service and employee compensation levels.
Eligibility is generally determined in accordance with local statutory requirements. Our U.S. retirees who retired prior to January&nbsp;1, 2005, are also covered by a lump sum death benefit that is
part of the Retiree Survivor's Benefit Plan. In July&nbsp;2004, the Retiree Survivor's Benefit Plan was revised to eliminate the $5,000 Retiree Survivor Benefit for all U.S. retirees who retire on
or after January&nbsp;1, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>93</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=93,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=640993,FOLIO='93',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EK1318A.;25',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:53' -->
<A NAME="page_ek1318_1_94"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;401(k) defined contribution plan.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our U.S. eligible employees may participate in the Agilent Technologies,&nbsp;Inc. 401(k)
Plan (the "401(k) Plan"). Enrollment in the 401(k) Plan is automatic for employees who meet eligibility requirements unless they decline participation. Under the 401(k) Plan, we provide matching
contributions to employees up to a maximum of 4&nbsp;percent of an employee's annual eligible compensation. The maximum contribution to the 401(k) Plan is 50&nbsp;percent of an employee's annual
eligible compensation, subject to regulatory and plan limitations. The 401(k) Plan expense included in income (loss) from continuing operations was $26&nbsp;million in 2006, $25&nbsp;million in
2005 and $25&nbsp;million in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Post-retirement medical benefit plans.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to receiving pension benefits, our U.S. employees who meet
retirement eligibility requirements as of their termination dates may participate in our Non-Medicare Medical or Medicare Medical Plans (the "Post-retirement Medical Plans")
under the Agilent Health Plan. Current U.S. employees may become eligible for these benefits, and the existing benefit obligation relates primarily to those employees. Once participating in a medical
plan, retirees may choose from managed-care and indemnity options, with their contributions dependent on the options chosen and length of service. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plan amendments.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July&nbsp;2004, the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors approved design changes to
Agilent's Post-retirement Medical Plans. One option available to existing post-65 retirees is a new Medicare Supplement Plan in 2005. The Medicare Supplement Plan supplements
Medicare coverage by reimbursing Medicare Parts A and B deductibles at 100&nbsp;percent after Medicare pays its portion of the retiree's expenses. The Post-retirement Medical Plan for a
majority of future retirees was revised to establish retiree medical accounts for the benefit of such retirees and will be funded with amounts as determined by Agilent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2003, the Medicare Prescription
Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 ("the Act") was passed which expands Medicare to include an outpatient prescription drug benefit beginning in 2006. In May&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued
FSP 106-2, "Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003", which provides guidance on how companies should
account for the impact of the Act on its postretirement healthcare plans. Beginning in 2006, the federal government provides a non-taxable subsidy to employers that sponsor prescription
drug benefits to retirees that are "actuarially equivalent" to Medicare Part&nbsp;D benefits. We have determined that the prescription drug benefits offered under our plans qualify for this subsidy
and assuming that we will continue to offer these benefits, we have reflected the expected subsidy according to the guidance in FSP 106-2 prospectively in our financial statements. The
adoption of FSP 106-2 had no material impact on our accumulated postretirement benefit obligation or net plan costs. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>94</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_ek1318_1_95"> </A>
<BR>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;1, 2005, due to the divestiture of the semiconductor products business, we recorded curtailments and settlements as required by SFAS No.&nbsp;88,
"Employers' Accounting for Settlements and Curtailments of Defined Benefit Pension Plans and for Termination Benefits," ("SFAS No.&nbsp;88") and as required under the SFAS No.&nbsp;106,
"Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions," ("SFAS No.&nbsp;106"). The impact to the U.S. Plans and the U.S. Post Retirement Benefit Plan was curtailment gains of
$22&nbsp;million and $21&nbsp;million, recorded in discontinued operations. The impact on the Non-U.S. Plans was a settlement gain of $8&nbsp;million recorded in discontinued
operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due
to the separation of our semiconductor test solutions business into a separate legal company, Verigy, as of June&nbsp;1, 2006, and due to significant workforce reductions, we
recorded curtailments and settlements as required by SFAS No.&nbsp;88 and SFAS No.&nbsp;106 in the third quarter. The impact to the U.S. Plans was a curtailment gain of $12&nbsp;million
consisting of curtailment gain of $3&nbsp;million for
continuing operations and curtailment gain of $9&nbsp;million for discontinued operations as well as a $4&nbsp;million settlement gain relating to continuing operations. The impact to the U.S.
Post Retirement Benefit Plan was a curtailment gain of $12&nbsp;million for continuing operations. The impact to the Non-U.S. Plans was a curtailment loss of $1&nbsp;million and a
settlement gain of $4&nbsp;million, that were recorded in discontinued operations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the U.S., because of additional workforce reductions along with cessation of retiree medical benefits for Verigy employees as of October&nbsp;31, 2006, we recorded curtailments and
settlements as required by SFAS No.&nbsp;88 and SFAS No.&nbsp;106 in the fourth quarter. The impact to the U.S. Plans was </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>95</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=95,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=159607,FOLIO='95',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EK1318A.;25',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:53' -->
<A NAME="page_ek1318_1_96"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>curtailment
gains of $2&nbsp;million and a settlement gain of $2&nbsp;million both of which were for continuing operations. For the U.S. Post Retirement Benefit Plan, we recorded a curtailment
gain of $5&nbsp;million which was for discontinued operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funded status.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of October&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the funded status of the defined benefit and
post-retirement benefit plans was: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>96</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=96,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=306737,FOLIO='96',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EK1318A.;25',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:53' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_em1318_1_97"> </A> </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment policies and strategies as of October&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2006.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plan assets consist primarily of publicly-traded
stocks and bonds. In the U.S., our Agilent Retirement Plan and post-retirement benefit assets are allocated approximately 80&nbsp;percent to equities and approximately 20&nbsp;percent
to fixed income investments. Our DPSP assets are allocated approximately 60&nbsp;percent to equities and approximately 40&nbsp;percent to fixed income investments. Approximately 10&nbsp;percent
of our U.S. equity portfolio consists of alternative investments, largely private equity partnerships. The general investment objective for all our plan assets is to obtain the optimum rate of
investment return on the total investment portfolio consistent with the assumption of a reasonable level of risk. The safety and protection of principal is a primary concern, and we believe that a
well-diversified investment portfolio will result in the highest attainable investment return (income plus capital appreciation) with the lowest overall risk. Specific investment
objectives for the plans' portfolios are to: maintain and enhance the purchasing power of the plans' assets; achieve investment returns consistent with the level of risk being taken; and earn
performance rates of return in accordance with the benchmarks adopted for each asset class. Outside the U.S., our assets are allocated from 50 to 70&nbsp;percent to equities, from 25 to
50&nbsp;percent to fixed income investments, and from 0 to 5&nbsp;percent to real estate investments, depending on the plan. All plans' assets are broadly diversified. The actual allocations of
plan assets are consistent with the target allocations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
table below presents the projected benefit obligation ("PBO"), accumulated benefit obligation ("ABO") and fair value of plan assets in the aggregate for all plans, separately showing
those that were considered under-funded as of October&nbsp;31, 2006 or 2005. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="95%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=5 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2006</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=5 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2005</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Benefit<BR>
Obligation</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Fair Value of<BR>
Plan Assets</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Benefit<BR>
Obligation</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Fair Value of<BR>
Plan Assets</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additional Minimum Liability.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An additional minimum pension liability adjustment was required in 2005 for three pension plans
in Europe as the accumulated benefit obligation exceeded the fair value of pension plan assets for those plans as of the measurement date. The impact of the additional minimum liability on accumulated
comprehensive loss was $170&nbsp;million, which was partially offset by $20&nbsp;million applied to deferred tax assets, net of tax valuation allowance. The large impact on accumulated
comprehensive income was primarily a result of prepaid costs that were reduced to zero in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;87, "Employers' Accounting for Pensions", for the impacted countries. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
June&nbsp;1, 2006, in accordance with the separation agreement between Agilent and Verigy, the liability for certain Verigy employee pension benefits was transferred to separate
Verigy pension plans. Agilent funded the pension liability to the extent of the accumulated benefit obligation out of operating cash. The funded status of the Non-U.S. plans required us to
reverse $58&nbsp;million of the additional minimum liability along with the related deferred tax impacts, of approximately $20&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An
additional minimum pension liability adjustment was required in 2006 for two pension plans in Europe as the accumulated benefit obligation exceeded the fair value of pension plan
assets for those plans as of the measurement date. The impact of the additional minimum liability on accumulated comprehensive gain (loss) was $112&nbsp;million which was partially offset by
$34&nbsp;million
applied to deferred tax assets. The large impact on accumulated comprehensive income was primarily a result of prepaid costs that were reduced to zero in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;87,
"Employers' Accounting for Pensions", for the impacted countries. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Contributions and estimated future benefit payments.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During fiscal year 2007, we expect to contribute zero to the U.S.
defined benefit plans, $39&nbsp;million to plans outside the U.S., and zero to the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>98</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Assumptions.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The assumptions used to determine the benefit obligations and expense for our defined benefit and
post-retirement benefit plans are presented in the table below. The expected long-term return on assets below represents an estimate of long-term returns on
investment portfolios consisting of a mixture of equities, fixed income and alternative investments in proportion to the asset allocations of each of our plans. We consider long-term rates
of return, which are weighted based, on the asset classes (both historical and forecasted) in which we expect our pension and post-retirement funds to be invested. Discount rates reflect
the current rate at which pension and post-retirement obligations could be settled based on the measurement dates of the plans&nbsp;&#151; October&nbsp;31 for the U.S. plans and
September&nbsp;30 for the non-U.S. plans. The U.S. discount rates were determined by matching the expected plan benefit payments against the cash flows from a hypothetically constructed
portfolio of high quality corporate bonds. The average yield of this hypothetical bond portfolio was used as a proxy for setting the discount rate. The non-U.S. rates were generally based
on published rates for high-quality corporate bonds. The range of assumptions that were used for the non-U.S. defined benefit plans reflects the different economic environments
within various countries. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>99</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>100</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=100,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=507827,FOLIO='100',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EM1318A.;12',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:47' -->
<A NAME="page_em1318_1_101"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Assumed
health care trend rates could have a significant effect on the amounts reported for Post-retirement Medical Plans. A one percentage point change in the assumed health
care cost trend rates for the year ended October&nbsp;31, 2006 would have the following effects: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="73%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="61%" ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>One<BR>
Percentage<BR>
Point<BR>
Increase</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>One<BR>
Percentage<BR>
Point<BR>
Decrease</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="61%" ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=5 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>(in millions)<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="61%"><FONT SIZE=2>Effect on total service and interest cost components</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="13%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>4</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="13%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>(3</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="61%"><FONT SIZE=2>Effect on post-retirement benefit obligations</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="13%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>52</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="13%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>(44</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Extended Warranty  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue from our extended warranty contracts with terms beyond one year is deferred and recognized on a straight-line basis over the contract period.
Related costs are expensed as incurred. Amounts representing warranty contracts for the next twelve months are included in deferred revenue on the consolidated balance sheet and were
$43&nbsp;million and $26&nbsp;million at October&nbsp;31, 2006 and October&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively. The long-term amounts are recorded in other liabilities on the consolidated
balance sheet and were $55&nbsp;million and $50&nbsp;million at October&nbsp;31, 2006 and October&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively. Also see Note&nbsp;20, "Other Accrued Liabilities and Other
Long-Term Liabilities." </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>101</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=101,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=146358,FOLIO='101',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EM1318A.;12',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:47' -->
<A NAME="page_em1318_1_102"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Lease Guarantees  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the quarter ended April&nbsp;30, 2005 we entered into an amended Vendor Finance agreement with CIT Group&nbsp;Inc. (formerly Tyco Capital Corporation)
that released Agilent from substantially all credit guarantees. As part of this agreement Agilent was also released of liability relating to the guarantees that could require us to repurchase
individual leases if the documentation we provided to support the lease was not materially accurate. The impact of the agreement was not material. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Indemnifications to Avago  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the sale of our semiconductor products business in December&nbsp;2005, we agreed to indemnify Avago, its affiliates and other related parties
against certain damages that it might incur in the future. These indemnifications primarily cover damages relating to liabilities of the businesses that Agilent retained and did not transfer to Avago,
as well as pre-closing taxes and other specified items. Agilent's indemnification for representations and warranties made to Avago are generally limited to 10&nbsp;percent of the
purchase price and survive until March&nbsp;31, 2007. In our opinion, the fair value of these indemnifications was not material as of October&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Indemnifications to Verigy  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the spin-off of Verigy, we agreed to indemnify Verigy and its affiliates against certain damages which it might incur in the
future. These indemnifications primarily cover damages relating to liabilities of the businesses that Agilent did not transfer to Verigy, liabilities that might arise under limited portions of
Verigy's IPO materials that relate to Agilent, and costs and expenses incurred by Agilent or Verigy to effect the IPO, arising out of the distribution of Agilent's remaining holding in Verigy ordinary
shares to Agilent's stockholders, or incurred to effect the separation of the semiconductor test solutions business from Agilent to the extent incurred prior to the separation on June&nbsp;1, 2006.
In our opinion, the fair value of these indemnifications was not material as of October&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Indemnifications to Hewlett-Packard  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have given multiple indemnities to Hewlett-Packard in connection with our activities prior to our spin-off from HP for the businesses that
constituted Agilent prior to the spin-off. These indemnifications cover a variety of aspects of our business, including, but not limited to, employee, tax, intellectual property and
environmental matters. The agreements containing these indemnifications have been previously disclosed as exhibits to our registration statement on Form&nbsp;S-1 filed on
August&nbsp;16, 1999. In our opinion, the fair value of these indemnifications was not material as of October&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Indemnifications to Officers and Directors  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our corporate by-laws require that we indemnify our officers and directors, as well as those who act as directors and officers of other entities at
our request, against expenses, judgments, fines, settlements and other amounts actually and reasonably incurred in connection with any proceedings arising out of their services to Agilent. In
addition, we have entered into separate indemnification agreements with each director and each board-appointed officer of Agilent which provide for indemnification of these directors and officers
under similar circumstances and under additional circumstances. The indemnification obligations are more fully described in the by-laws and the indemnification agreements. We purchase
standard insurance to cover claims or a portion of the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>102</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=102,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=36614,FOLIO='102',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EM1318A.;12',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:47' -->
<A NAME="page_em1318_1_103"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>claims
made against our directors and officers. Since a maximum obligation is not explicitly stated in our by-laws or in our indemnification agreements and will depend on the facts and
circumstances that arise out of any future claims, the overall maximum amount of the obligations cannot be reasonably estimated. Historically, we have not made payments related to these obligations,
and the fair value for these obligations was zero on the consolidated balance sheet as of October&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Other Indemnifications  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As is customary in our industry and as provided for in local law in the U.S. and other jurisdictions, many of our standard contracts provide remedies to our
customers and others with whom we enter into contracts, such as defense, settlement, or payment of judgment for intellectual property claims related to the use of our products. From time to time, we
indemnify customers, as well as our suppliers, contractors, lessors, lessees, companies that purchase our businesses or assets and others with whom we enter into contracts, against combinations of
loss, expense, or liability arising from various triggering events related to the sale and the use of our products and services, the use of their goods and services, the use of facilities and state of
our owned facilities, the state of the assets and businesses that we sell and other matters covered by such contracts, usually up to a specified maximum amount. In addition, from time to time we also
provide protection to these parties against claims related to undiscovered liabilities, additional product liability or environmental obligations. In our experience, claims made under such
indemnifications are rare and the associated estimated fair value of the liability was not material as of October&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>18.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments and Contingencies  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Lease Commitments:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We lease certain real and personal property from unrelated third parties under
non-cancelable operating leases. Future minimum lease payments under operating leases related to continuing operations at October&nbsp;31, 2006 were $79&nbsp;million for 2007,
$62&nbsp;million for 2008, $44&nbsp;million for 2009, $25&nbsp;million for 2010, $16&nbsp;million for 2011 and $37&nbsp;million thereafter. Future minimum sublease income under leases at
October&nbsp;31, 2006 was $12&nbsp;million for 2007, $10&nbsp;million for 2008, $6&nbsp;million for 2009, $2&nbsp;million for 2010 and zero for 2011. Certain leases require us to pay
property taxes, insurance and routine maintenance, and include escalation clauses. Total rent expense, including amounts recorded in discontinued operations, was $112&nbsp;million in 2006,
$90&nbsp;million in 2005 and $116&nbsp;million in 2004. Rent expense recorded in discontinued operations was $2&nbsp;million in 2006, $23&nbsp;million in 2005 and $25&nbsp;million in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
are involved in lawsuits, claims, investigations and proceedings, including patent, commercial and environmental matters. There are no matters pending that we expect to be material in
relation to our business, consolidated financial condition, results of operations or cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>19.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restructuring and Asset Impairment  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We initiated several restructuring plans in prior periods: the 2001 Plan, the 2002 Plan and the 2003 Plan ("Prior Plans"). The workforce reduction portion of the
Prior Plans was completed during fiscal year 2005. The consolidation of excess facilities portion of Prior Plans is expected to be completed within approximately the next five years. In addition,
there may be future changes in estimates for the consolidation of excess facilities related to changes in market conditions from those originally expected at the time the charges were recorded. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>103</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=103,EFW="2175273",CP="AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES",DN="1",CHK=45026,FOLIO='103',FILE='DISK132:[06PAL8.06PAL1318]EM1318A.;12',USER='JKARRAS',CD='22-DEC-2006;13:47' -->
<A NAME="page_em1318_1_104"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the fourth quarter of 2005, as a consequence of the decision to divest the semiconductor products and semiconductor test solutions businesses, we launched a new restructuring program
(the "2005 Plan") to align our workforce with our smaller organizational size. The 2005 Plan consists purely of workforce reduction initiatives, and is primarily focused on reducing the costs
associated with the shared services functions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
summary of total restructuring activity, including that classified as discontinued operations, is shown in the table below: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
restructuring accrual for all plans, which totaled $71&nbsp;million at October&nbsp;31, 2006 and $93&nbsp;million at October&nbsp;31, 2005, is recorded in other accrued
liabilities and other long-term liabilities on the consolidated balance sheet and represents estimated future cash outlays. Workforce reduction expenses, primarily severance, are expected
to be largely completed by the end of fiscal 2007. In 2006, we consolidated several facilities due to changes in our organizational structure and recorded impairment charges of $42&nbsp;million.
These charges were primarily associated with facilities located in Germany and the US. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>104</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>20.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Accrued Liabilities and Other Long-Term Liabilities  </B></FONT></P>
